description: Dive into "Sorrento's Coastal Bliss: Beach Escapes" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Sorrento's Coastal Bliss: Beach Escapes

places.generalDescription: La Terrazza is a terrace bar with stunning sunset views, offering memorable cocktails and occasional live performances. While the food and drinks are pricier compared to other places in Sant Agnello, the breathtaking view of the Sorrento coastline and Mount Vesuvius makes it worth it. Some visitors found the food to be average, but others raved about dishes like seafood linguine and Sorrentina style cod.
places.name: La Terrazza

reviews.text: The food was delicious, and the view was priceless.  We came here for breakfast at around 10AM, and it was not crowded. Waitress was friendly and attentive. We will probably be coming here for breakfast during our week stay.  We will try them for dinner tonight and post that then.

This is in a fabulous location on a protruding  clifftop looking alo g the coast towards Sorrento. You don't need to go to the restaurant to use the viewing platform, but if you do fancy a drink or whatever, these are top Amalfi coast prices. Worth it for the views across the bay  anyway, and amazingly from Sorrento and San Angel, nowhere near a polluted road blocked with traffic.

The view especially when sun set earned my 5 stars. Food quality can be subjective but good enough for me to come back twice. A bit pricey compared to other restaurants in the proximity but it's understandable

places.generalDescription: Nestled at the edge of Sorrento, Bagni Regina Giovanna is a captivating destination that combines history with natural beauty. A leisurely 35-40 minute walk leads you to the remnants of an ancient Roman villa, where you'll discover a stunning hidden cove. This secluded spot features a natural archway through which crystal-clear waters flow into a tranquil pool, making it an ideal retreat for those seeking solace away from crowded beaches.

sources.snippet: One of the most popular and beautiful beaches in Sorrento is Bagni Regina Giovana, also known as Baths of Queen Giovanna. There is a natural pool around rocks and some greenery that you can swim in. Look for a hidden path that’ll take you through to the beach!
sources.shortName: Does Sorrento in Italy have a beach?

sources.snippet: Bagni della Regina Giovanna (Baths of Queen Giovanna), is a protected pool of emerald green sea water, separated by a natural limestone archway from the open sea.

sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Attractions & Things to Do in Sorrento

places.name: Bagni Regina Giovanna

reviews.text:
A local who lives in the U.S. now recommend this spot to us.  It took a bus and a 15 minute walk, but it was our second best day in Sorrento.  It was busy, but not packed.  A few tourists but a lot of locals.  We felt like locals.  We bought sandwiches in town, wine, and made a day of it.  Highly recommend!

Be respectful and take your trash out.

Beautiful spot. About a 15-minute walk from the bus stop. The path is manageable, but the final steps down to the water can be a bit tricky-especially if you're wearing flip-flops. Overall, definitely worth a visit for a refreshing swim in a unique setting.

Bagni della Regina Giovanna is an interesting spot with beautiful views and a natural swimming pool carved into the rock. The place itself is picturesque and unique. The best way is to take a bus from Sorrento and then walk about 15 minutes to reach the beach. In the high season, it gets very crowded, which makes it hard to fully enjoy. Worth visiting once for the views and history, but not a place I would rush back to.

places.address: Traversa Punta Capo, 80067 Sorrento NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: Capo di Sorrento is a stunning natural enclave just a mile away from Sorrento, making it an ideal destination for trekking and hiking. Visitors can take a beautiful walk to the great Roman Villa on the headland, which was once Queen Giovanna's favorite bathing place. The area offers lovely views of ancient city remains and cliffs, with clear waters perfect for diving.

sources.snippet: At the Capo di Sorrento, greeted by acres of olive groves, you can dive off the cliffs of the Queen Giovanna; a few meters from the remains of a Roman villa which belonged to the nobleman Pollio Felice. Just beyond, an area LGBT-friendly: the wide expanse of rocks La Solara.

places.name: Capo di Sorrento

reviews.text: I visited Bagni Regina Giovanna with my husband and a group of friends, and it was an unforgettable experience. The place is absolutely stunning - surrounded by nature with crystal-clear water that's perfect for swimming. We all had such a fun and relaxing time. It's a peaceful spot that feels like a hidden gem. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area!

We walked here in hope of a more historical experience. The view was pretty good but personally, I'm not too sure if it made up for the 45 minute walk from the Sorrento town centre as there were sections where pedestrians had to walk along the busy, narrow roads with no dedicated pedestrian footpath. There were a good number of people laying down for a tan at Capo Di Sorrento and I guess it was okay if that's what one wanted, or perhaps wanted a swim. Fishing was also something that some were visibly enjoying! Free entry, free swimming and free sunbathing!

Found this place by accident and loved it.

Great views and history.

Path at the bottom of the hill is scetchy but worth the effort

places.generalDescription: Bagni Salvatore is the final beach club in Sorrento's Marina Piccolo, boasting a rich history dating back to 1930. It has been a popular destination for families from Naples and wider Europe due to its stunning coastline. The establishment offers excellent service, delectable food, and breathtaking views that keep visitors coming back.

sources.snippet: Additionally, there are rentals of pedal boats, canoes and cabins. Of course, there is a delicious restaurant and bar. Prices: Bed @ 13 euro.

places.name: Bagni Salvatore

reviews.text: I chose Bagni Salvatore after careful consideration of how we could best spend our singular day of relaxation during our holiday- which happened to coincide with Easter Sunday. I messaged about a month in advance enquiring as to if the beach would be open and if they could cater to vegetarians, and I found the correspondence to be prompt and hospitable. Once we arrived we were met with the warm and gracious hospitality that southern Italy is so famous for. We had multiple people looking after us and making sure we were happy. We spent the entire day here and it is one of the happiest memories we made during our trip. Wonderful place, do yourself a favour and spend a day here!

We had a wonderful time at Bagni Salvatore! The beach club is located a short walk from the ferry port and relatively easy to find. Compared to other beach clubs we looked at, the prices were very reasonable! The staff was very kind and accommodating. The drinks were good and the food was tasty. The scenery was beautiful and the location offered a bit of privacy as it was the last beach club on the strip. The only thing I wish is that they had played music or I had brought headphones. Overall we had an incredible time!

We visited this private beach and had a wonderful experience. The location is stunning - crystal-clear turquoise water right in front of ancient Roman ruins, which added so much charm and value to the day. Truly beautiful.

We made our reservation the night before by sending a message on Instagram, and they replied instantly. The only condition was to arrive before 11:00 am so the reservation would be honored. We got there right on time, around 10:55/11:00, and were given premium spots in a perfect location.

The water was calm and beautiful to swim in, and the sunbeds were very comfortable. We brought our own snacks and drinks, which was no problem at all, and we also ordered some drinks on site. The staff was very attentive and friendly throughout the day.

The entrance fee is €30 per person. I understand some people may find it expensive to pay for beach access, but in this area (Sorrento/Amalfi Coast), beaches are mostly private and man-made. Considering how expensive the region is in general, I think €30 is absolutely worth it. Coming from Berlin, where a nightclub entrance easily costs €20–30, paying the same for a full day under the sun in such a beautiful setting felt more than fair.

We stayed until around 6:30 pm, enjoyed the sun the whole day, and the place never felt overcrowded. Overall, money very well spent and an experience I 100% recommend.

places.generalDescription: Rugged, rocky strand backed by greenery-covered cliffs, popular for sunbathing & sunset views.

sources.snippet: The beautiful Pignatella Beach is located between Sorrento and Massa Lubrense; made up of large, smooth, flat stones that act as sunbathing areas, with sun loungers and umbrellas available to hire. To get in and out of the water you need to use the system of ropes and ladders attached to these stone platforms.

places.name: the Pignatella Beach

reviews.text: Amazing beach to visit, with not a lot of people.

Wonderful views, clear water and a parking space in the olive grove. Simply fantastic. The parking lot is large.     There is no beach but it is a large cliff that allows you to sit down .Not suitable for children. It is also possible to rent sunbeds. Magnificent place, cliff overlooking clear sea. Parking alone costs is some high. Not very convenient but well frequented, with parking. The sea is wonderful, in color and clarity. Parking is mandatory. The beach is small and tends to be crowded, while the cliff is wide, very windy and well frequented, which allows you to enjoy a day at the beach even in hotter and more crowded periods.You get to the beach via a path of a few minutes. there are Beautiful water and spectacular sunset on Ischia area
Wouldn't say its a swimming spot unless you had scuba shoes. Great sunbathing spot

places.address: Via Marina di Puolo, 80061 Marina di Puolo NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: Puolo Beach is a serene and charming sandy beach situated on the western side of the Sorrentine Peninsula, offering stunning views of lush green hills and crystal-clear waters. It's an ideal spot for a romantic day out or even a marriage proposal. The beach provides a tranquil setting for couples to enjoy a leisurely stroll along the coastal path as the sun sets. The water is clean and safe for children, making it perfect for families as well.

sources.snippet: A beautiful beach where you rent chairs and an umbrella to enjoy the calm clear waters slowly crashing into the sand and gravel. As you go out into the sparkling blue water for a swim, you might see fish, rock crabs, and purple and green plants. Bring some goggles if you can so you can see marine life and plants clearer underwater.
sources.shortName: Does Sorrento in Italy have a beach?

sources.snippet: There are several bars and restaurants on the beach, serving fresh fish dishes and delicious local wine along with beers and soft drinks. There is also a solarium with sun loungers, umbrellas and deckchairs, pedal boats for hire or boats that can be rented or chartered for the day.

places.name: Puolo Beach

reviews.text: This restaurant served the best fried mixed fish I've ever had (and I've had lots). The variety of the fish was excellent, I counted at least 7 x types, including prawns, octopus and snapper. The portion almost beat me... you'll not leave the table hungry! The staff are friendly and helpful, even blagging me a 1€ ride back up the hill on the 3 x wheeled chug chug - it is steep and long. The bus ride from Sorrento to the beach costs 1.80€ and takes about 20 minutes. This is a FREE beach, whereas the 'platforms' closer to Sorrento can cost up to 50€ to use.
Off the beaten track beach right near Sorrento for a less touristy atmosphere

Lovely beach, we went just to the right and sat near the rocky cove, water gets deep enough to swim easily. 2 sunbeds and umbrella 30 euros. Top tip would be arrive early, we got there around 11:30 and still plenty of sunbeds so before then would probably get to the front by the sea. We managed to get a TukTuk back up the hill, which was a lifesaver in the heat. That was at 3pm, may be difficult to get if gets busy later.

places.generalDescription: Marameo Beach Club, one of the oldest beach clubs in Sorrento, has recently undergone a complete renovation to offer top-notch facilities. With 30 changing rooms, king-size loungers, floating sunbeds, and even private jacuzzis available for those seeking luxury. The club also boasts a restaurant serving lunch and dinner daily.

sources.snippet: Marameo Beaches has 30 changing cabins, floating sun beds, king size sun beds, leisure zone with giant sofa, chaise lounge and Jacuzzi. The restaurant is open daily for lunch and dinner. Prices: Beds @ 14 euros, Towels @ 3 euros

places.name: Marameo Beach Club

reviews.text: We had the most incredible time! Literally everything (food, service, and atmosphere) was perfect. The staff was so helpful and friendly. My husband and I will be recommending this beach club to anyone visiting Sorrento! We will definitely be back!

I can't say enough about Gino! We walked up not knowing which beach to choose and he sold us with his kindness, energy, and hospitality.  He placed us in the best place with 2 chairs and umbrella. Checked on us all the time. Such a great person with a wonderful personality. Thank you Gino! Next time in Sorrento, we will be coming back to see you! Ciao!

If you're searching for the best resort in Sorrento, look no further than Gino and his amazing team including Tony and Carmine. From the moment we arrived, the hospitality was truly world-class – warm, welcoming, and always professional.

The food and drinks were outstanding, easily some of the best we had in Sorrento. Every meal felt authentic and fresh, and the cocktails were unforgettable.

The real highlight is the grotto in Sorrento – the perfect place to swim, cool off, and relax with great music in a unique setting. It's a hidden gem that makes this resort stand out from anywhere else in the Amalfi Coast.

We will absolutely be returning every time we are in Sorrento. Highly recommend this resort for anyone looking for the ultimate combination of luxury, good vibes, and authentic Italian hospitality.

places.address: Spiaggia San Francesco, Via Marina Piccola, 80067 Sorrento NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: Onoranze Funebri Marciano Sorrento di Ferdinando Marciano - Agenzia Funebre Sorrento - Cremazioni is a notable establishment that embodies experience, precision, and professionalism in its services. While it may not be directly related to leisure activities, the surrounding area offers unique attractions such as Captain Cook, the first pet beach in Campania.

sources.snippet: Point of interest in Marciano is the first pet beach of the Campania region. The resort is called ‘Captain Cook’, where your four-legged friends are welcome. And it is just in front Capri Island.

places.name: Onoranze Funebri Marciano Sorrento di Ferdinando Marciano - Agenzia Funebre Sorrento - Cremazioni

reviews.text:
(Translated by Google) Experience, precision and professionalism

(Original)
Esperienza,precisione e professionalita'

places.address: Via degli Aranci, 29/E, 80067 Sorrento NA, Italy

places.generalDescription: Ristorante Bagni Sant'Anna is a charming restaurant located on the seafront in Marina Grande, offering stunning views of the Gulf of Naples. The establishment includes a bar, restaurant, and solarium where guests can enjoy aperitifs, dinner, and even access to the beach club. The menu focuses on fish-based specialties prepared with carefully selected local ingredients. In the evening, the magical sea views are enhanced by enchanting lights and a lively atmosphere.
places.name: Ristorante Bagni Sant'Anna

reviews.text: Food was amazing! I have food allergies and they were so careful and nice about it.  They even have a page in the back of the menu that lists the top food allergens with pictures to make it easier to communicate across different languages!  The servers were so friendly and spent 10+ min helping us try to find a taxi when none were available.  It wasn't overly crowded so we were able to sit and enjoy the food and view on the water.  Would absolutely go back again!

The restaurant is literally located on the water on a floating dock. It is a no frills restaurant that does seafood right.  My guess is everything we ate was swimming in the sea earlier in the day.

We had fried calamari as an appetizer and it was perfectly cooked.  Served with fries, which was a bit odd, but no biggie.

We had cheese ravioli for Primi.  Again, perfectly cooked with a nice light tomato ragu.

For secondi we went with a special they offered us.  It was a whole sea bass with broccoli and small potatoes.  Light butter lemon dressing.  Perfectly cooked and served tableside by the waiter who plucked it clean onto our plates with the traditional for and spoon technique.

Complementary Limoncello at the end of the meal.  Two rounds.

Service was impeccable.

So why not five stars?  It was the bill.  We were surprised by the price of the fish.  It doesn't matter what it was.  I would just ask the server if you are offered a special what is the cost.

We have had great meals in Sorrento for about 25% less.  This was not fine dining.
We were careless and got burned.

Note: The map picture.  Red pin for restaurant and blue dot for our table.

It was still a wonderful night, and yes, we would absolutely go back.

I had the pleasure of dining at Ristorante Bagni Sant'Anna during a recent trip to Sorrento, and the experience was nothing short of magical.

Set directly on the water's edge, the restaurant offers breathtaking views of the sea – and as the sun began to set, we found ourselves dining against the most spectacular golden backdrop. It was one of those moments where the setting alone already felt special.

The food was equally impressive. We began with a beautifully grilled fish – light, clean in flavour, and not in the least bit dry. The squid was another highlight: perfectly tender and full of smoky, chargrilled character. The seafood pasta was truly memorable, with wonderfully chewy noodles and a rich, savoury sauce that brought everything together.

For dessert, we enjoyed a selection of canelé, tiramisu, and lemon cake – all delicious in their own right and a perfect way to end the meal. Each sweet offered a different texture and flavour, yet all were executed with finesse.

What truly made the evening unforgettable, however, was the arrival of an elderly gentleman with a guitar just as the sun touched the horizon. He began to play O Sole Mio and other classics, and suddenly the entire atmosphere shifted – as if we had been transported into a romantic film. It was spontaneous, heartfelt, and incredibly moving.

The only regret I have is not being able to leave a tip for the musician, as I didn't have any cash on me – something I truly felt sorry for.

In every way, this was a flawless dining experience – from the food to the view to the atmosphere. I wholeheartedly recommend Ristorante Bagni Sant'Anna to anyone visiting Sorrento. It's the kind of place that lingers in your memory long after the sun has set.

places.address: Via del Mare, 150, 80067 Sorrento NA, Italy
